title: 109_s2139
content: The "Earned Income Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2005" may be cited as the short title. It includes a modification of the abandoned spouse rule. The "Earned Income Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2005" includes a provision for certain married individuals living apart to be considered unmarried for tax purposes if they meet specific criteria. The "Earned Income Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2005" allows married individuals living apart to be considered unmarried for tax purposes under certain conditions. The amendments made by this act apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2005. SEC. 3. SIMPLIFICATION OF RULES REGARDING PRESENCE OF QUALIFYING CHILD. Taxpayer eligible for credit for worker without qualifying child if qualifying child claimed by another family member. An eligible individual without a qualifying child can claim the credit if no other parent claims the child as a qualifying child. An eligible individual without a qualifying child may be considered for the tax credit if their qualifying children do not have a valid Social Security number. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2005. SEC. 4 eliminates the disqualified investment income test in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2005. SEC. 5 defines a valid taxpayer identification number for the Earned Income Credit. The amendment to Section 32(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 specifies that a taxpayer identification number for the Earned Income Credit must be a social security number authorized for employment purposes. The amendment to Section 32(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires that the Earned Income Credit can only be claimed if the earned income is attributable to the spouse whose social security number is authorized for employment purposes. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2005, and the Treasury Secretary must notify affected households at least 3 months in advance. The amendment to Section 32(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires individuals with an employment-authorized social security number to take action to maintain eligibility for the earned income credit. If eligibility conditions are not met, the Treasury Secretary will notify taxpayers of the necessary steps to qualify for the credit and the option to file an amended tax return if eligibility cannot be established. If eligibility for the earned income credit cannot be established within the response period for a mathematical or clerical error notice.
